(41) Furthermore, gain and offerings disturb the practice of the Way. If one cuts off gain and offerings, one should observe and contemplate
anger.
I once heard that there was a bhiká¹£u in a garden who was competed for by cities and villages to make offerings. Those who had left the household life together gave rise to jealousy and slander.
The bhiká¹£u's disciples heard this slander and said to their teacher:

The disciples said to their teacher:

The teacher replied:
That slanderer has a kindness towards me and should be made offerings.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
Just as hail can destroy crops, if someone is able to stop it,
The owner of the field will be overjoyed and repay them with wealth and silk.
Those who slander are close friends, not enemies,
They stop the hail of my offerings, I should repay their kindness.
Hail only harms for one lifetime, offerings harm many bodies,
Hail only destroys wealth, offerings destroy the practice of the Way.
For a field harmed by hail, there will certainly be some remaining,
But for that harmed by offerings, all merit is completely destroyed.
Just like Devadatta, harmed by the hail of offerings,
Because of his greed, there is not a hair's worth of goodness,
Evil is extremely rampant, upon death he falls into a bad path.
Offerings are more intense than a raging fire, and even surpass evil poison,
Lions, tigers, and wolves.
The wise, having observed this, would rather be harmed by them than be harmed by gain and offerings.
The foolish, greedy for gain and offerings, do not see their faults.
Gain and offerings distance one from the holy path, and good conduct is destroyed and does not arise.
The Buddha has already severed all bonds, and the bonds of the three existences are completely unraveled.
His merits are already fully complete, yet he still avoids gain and offerings.
In the midst of the assembly, he roars like a lion and proclaims these words:
Do not come near me with gain and offerings, and I also keep far away from them.
Who among those with a clear and wise mind would be greedy for gain and offerings?
Gain and offerings disturb the mind of concentration, and the harm is worse than an enemy.
It is like cutting through the skin with a hair rope, breaking the flesh and bones,
and stopping only when the marrow is severed.
It severs the skin of upholding precepts, breaks the flesh of meditative concentration,
and shatters the bones of wisdom, destroying the marrow of the wondrous good mind.
It is like an infant who grasps at fire, wanting to eat it,
Like a fish swallowing a hook and bait, like a bird covered by a net,

Bhiká¹£us who crave for offerings are no different from them,
Their taste is extremely meager, but the harm they bring is very deep and heavy.
Those who deceive and flatter live among offerings,
Close to confusion and chaos, the seeds of trouble and harm,
Like someone with scabies scratching a sore, the itch increases as they scratch,
Arrogance, indulgence, and desire all arise from offerings.
This person is our enemy, blocking our offerings,
For this reason, we should wholeheartedly make offerings to him.
How can such a good friend be called an enemy?
Because of craving for offerings, he does not enjoy quiet places,
The mind always thinks of gain, day and night without rest.
There are clothes and food there, and so-and-so is my close friend,
He will certainly come and invite me, the mind has many attachments.
Ruining the peaceful mind, not enjoying secluded places,
Always delighting in the human realm, because of the ruin of agricultural profits.
Not delighting in the Dharma of tranquil concentration, because of abandoning tranquil concentration,
Not called a bhiká¹£u, also not called a layperson.
